skill.name: pennylane
skill.description: Cross-platform Python library for quantum computing, quantum machine learning, and quantum chemistry. Enables building and training quantum circuits with automatic differentiation, seamless integration with PyTorch/JAX/TensorFlow, and device-independent execution across simulators and quantum hardware (IBM, Amazon Braket, Google, Rigetti, IonQ, etc.). Use when working with quantum circuits, variational quantum algorithms (VQE, QAOA), quantum neural networks, hybrid quantum-classical models, molecular simulations, quantum chemistry calculations, or any quantum computing tasks requiring gradient-based optimization, hardware-agnostic programming, or quantum machine learning workflows.
skill.summary: Cross-platform Python library for quantum computing, quantum machine learning, and quantum chemistry...

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing educational Python code examples for quantum computing workflows. No executable scripts, network calls, file system access, or environment variable reads. All content matches the stated purpose of teaching PennyLane quantum computing patterns.

content.value_statement: Quantum computing tasks require specialized knowledge of circuit design and optimization. PennyLane provides a unified interface for building, training, and executing quantum circuits with automatic differentiation across simulators and real hardware.
actual_capabilities: Build quantum circuits with single and multi-qubit gates
Train variational quantum algorithms with automatic differentiation
Execute circuits on simulators or quantum hardware
Integrate with PyTorch, JAX, and TensorFlow workflows
Compute molecular Hamiltonians for quantum chemistry
limitations: Quantum hardware access requires additional plugins
Circuit size limited by simulator resources
Gradient-based training may face barren plateaus

best_practices: Start with simulators before deploying to quantum hardware
Use parameter-shift rule for gradient computation on hardware
Initialize parameters carefully to avoid barren plateaus
Cache device objects to reduce initialization overhead
anti_patterns: Using backpropagation on quantum hardware (only works on simulators)
Skipping circuit validation on simulators before hardware execution
Using too many qubits beyond simulator capacity
Ignoring noise models when simulating hardware behavior

faq.question: What quantum hardware does PennyLane support?
faq.answer: IBM Quantum, Amazon Braket, Google Cirq, Rigetti, IonQ, and Azure Quantum through device plugins.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of qubits for simulation?
faq.answer: default.qubit handles ~25 qubits; lightning.qubit extends to ~30 qubits depending on available memory.

faq.question: How does PennyLane integrate with PyTorch?
faq.answer: Use interface='torch' in QNode decorator; PennyLane tensors are compatible with torch.autograd.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using cloud quantum hardware?
faq.answer: Circuit definitions are sent to hardware providers; sensitive data should be minimized in circuit parameters.

faq.question: Why are my gradients vanishing?
faq.answer: Barren plateaus affect deep circuits; try initialization strategies, shallower circuits, or local cost functions.

faq.question: How does PennyLane compare to Qiskit or Cirq?
faq.answer: PennyLane focuses on variational algorithms and automatic differentiation; Qiskit and Cirq are lower-level frameworks.
